description: From Middle English gilden, gulden, from Old English gyldan (“to gild, to cover with a thin layer of gold”), from Proto-West Germanic *gulþijan, from Proto-Germanic *gulþijaną, from Proto-Germanic *gulþą (“gold”).

verbs.description: gild (third-person singular simple present gilds, present participle gilding, simple past and past participle gilded or gilt)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To cover with a thin layer of gold; to cover with gold leaf.
(transitive, cooking) To decorate with a golden surface appearance.
examples: Gild the entire outside with beaten egg yolk, and sprinkle it with grated parmesan.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To give a bright or pleasing aspect to.

examples: No trade gild might be started without the consent of the whole body of hanasters, who would insist that the regulations were not harmful to the burgesses as a whole;  […]
